original_text: The propagation of unsteady disturbances in ducts of slowly-varying geometry, such as those typical of an aeroengine, can be successfully modelled using a multiple scales approach. From the first application [1] of multiple-scales analysis to sound propagation in ducts of rectangular and circular cross section without mean flow, more recent developments have extended the method to cases with uniform mean flow [2], mean swirling flow [3], ducts of arbitrary cross section [4] (with uniform mean flow) and strongly curved ducts [5]. The multiple-scales approach has a number of distinct advantages over full numerical methods as it is ideally suited to handle higher frequencies and the computational complexity is only marginally more than calculating the eigenmodes inside a straight parallel duct. The accuracy and usefulness of the multiple scales approach has been validated against finite-element methods [6] for realistic aeroengine configurations and acoustic frequencies [7,8].
original_translation: La propagación de perturbaciones inestables en conductos de geometría lentamente variable, como los típicos de un motor aeroespacial, puede ser modelada con éxito utilizando un enfoque de múltiples escalas. Desde la primera aplicación [1] del análisis de múltiples escalas a la propagación del sonido en conductos de sección transversal rectangular y circular sin flujo medio, desarrollos más recientes han extendido el método a casos con flujo medio uniforme [2], flujo medio vorticoso [3], conductos de sección transversal arbitraria [4] (con flujo medio uniforme) y conductos fuertemente curvados [5]. El enfoque de múltiples escalas tiene varias ventajas distintas sobre los métodos numéricos completos, ya que es ideal para manejar frecuencias más altas y la complejidad computacional es solo marginalmente mayor que calcular los modos propios dentro de un conducto recto y paralelo. La precisión y utilidad del enfoque de múltiples escalas ha sido validada contra métodos de elementos finitos [6] para configuraciones realistas de motores aeroespaciales y frecuencias acústicas [7,8].
original_sentences: The propagation of unsteady disturbances in ducts of slowly-varying geometry, such as those typical of an aeroengine, can be successfully modelled using a multiple scales approach.

From the first application [1] of multiple-scales analysis to sound propagation in ducts of rectangular and circular cross section without mean flow, more recent developments have extended the method to cases with uniform mean flow [2], mean swirling flow [3], ducts of arbitrary cross section [4] (with uniform mean flow) and strongly curved ducts [5].

The multiple-scales approach has a number of distinct advantages over full numerical methods as it is ideally suited to handle higher frequencies and the computational complexity is only marginally more than calculating the eigenmodes inside a straight parallel duct.
The accuracy and usefulness of the multiple scales approach has been validated against finite-element methods [6] for realistic aeroengine configurations and acoustic frequencies [7,8].

La propagación de perturbaciones inestables en conductos de geometría lentamente variable, como los típicos de un motor aeroespacial, puede ser modelada con éxito utilizando un enfoque de múltiples escalas. Desde la primera aplicación [1] del
análisis de múltiples escalas
a la propagación del sonido en conductos de sección transversal rectangular y circular sin flujo medio, desarrollos más recientes han extendido el método a casos con flujo medio uniforme [2], flujo medio vorticoso [3], conductos de sección transversal arbitraria [4] (con flujo medio uniforme) y conductos fuertemente curvados [5]. El enfoque de múltiples escalas tiene varias ventajas distintas sobre los métodos numéricos completos, ya que es ideal para manejar frecuencias más altas y la complejidad computacional es solo marginalmente mayor que calcular los modos propios dentro de un conducto recto y paralelo. La precisión y utilidad del enfoque de múltiples escalas ha sido validada contra métodos de elementos finitos [6] para configuraciones realistas de motores aeroespaciales y frecuencias acústicas [7,8].

original_annotated_sentences:
The propagation of unsteady disturbances in ducts of slowly-varying geometry, such as those typical of an aeroengine, can be successfully modelled using a
multiple scales approach
.

From the first application [1] of multiple-scales analysis to sound propagation in ducts of rectangular and circular cross section without mean flow, more recent developments have extended the method to cases with uniform mean flow [2], mean swirling flow [3], ducts of arbitrary cross section [4] (with uniform mean flow) and strongly curved ducts [5].

The multiple-scales approach has a number of distinct advantages over full numerical methods as it is ideally suited to handle higher frequencies and the computational complexity is only marginally more than calculating the eigenmodes inside a straight parallel duct.

The accuracy and usefulness of the
multiple scales approach
has been validated against finite-element methods [6] for realistic aeroengine configurations and acoustic frequencies [7,8].

ha sido validada contra métodos de elementos finitos [6] para configuraciones realistas de motores aeroespaciales y frecuencias acústicas [7,8].
